#Text=Mushulatubbee
#Text=Warning : Page using Template : Infobox officeholder with unknown parameter " religion " ( this message is shown only in preview ) .

#Text=Mushulatubbee ( Choctaw AmoshuliTabi , " Determined to Kill " ) ( born c. 1750 – 1770 , died c. 1838 ) was the chief of the Choctaw Okla Tannap ( " Lower Towns " ) , one of the three major Choctaw divisions during the early 19th century .
#Text=When the Principal Chief Greenwood LeFlore stayed in Mississippi at the time of removal , Mushulatubbee was elected as principal chief , leading the tribe to Indian Territory .
#Text=In 1812 he had led his warriors to assist General Andrew Jackson in the war against the Creek Red Sticks , known as the Creek Wars .
#Text=In December 1824 Mushulatubbee was one of three principal chiefs leading a Choctaw delegation to Washington to seek help against encroaching European-American settlers .

#Text=Pushmataha and Apuckshunubbee were the other chiefs ; Apuckshunubbee , age 80 , died before they reached Washington , and Pushmataha died of illness in the capital soon after their meeting with the government .

#Text=On 26 September 1830 , together with the Principal Chief Greenwood LeFlore and others , Mushulatubbee signed the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek , which ceded to the US government most of the remaining Choctaw territory in Mississippi and Alabama in exchange for territory in Indian Territory .
#Text=Other spellings for his name include : Mosholetvbbi , AmoshuliTvbi , Musholatubbee , Moshaleh Tubbee , and Mushulatubba .
#Text=Creek Wars
#Text=The great Shawnee leader Tecumseh visited Mushulatubbee in 1811 when he came south to get support for his Great Confederacy , in an effort to push out the European Americans .
#Text=Today it is known as Tecumseh 's Confederacy .
#Text=Tecumseh met Moshulatubbee at his village Mashulaville ( located in present-day Noxubee County , Mississippi ) .
#Text=He was chief of Okla Tannap ( Lower Towns ) , the southern division of the three major geographic and clan Choctaw areas of settlement .
#Text=Other major divisions were in the northeast , including part of Alabama ; and the west , near Vicksburg .
#Text=Mushulatubbee had sympathy for Tecumseh and his cause , but decided he was too old to do anything for the confederacy , so remained neutral .
#Text=In addition to fighting with Jackson and his forces against the Creek , Mushulatubbee led 52 Choctaw warriors in the Battle of New Orleans in 1814 .
#Text=They fought in the swamps and cypress trees , picking off many British pickets and demoralizing them .
#Text=They kept shooting down the Red Coats , as they were fighting for their homeland .
#Text=When the Battle of New Orleans was over , Moshulatubbee and his 52 warriors returned home .
#Text=They left the service on January 27 , 1815 , from Fort Stoddard .
#Text=Land cessions

#Text=Under continuing pressure from European-American settlers and the United States government , Mushulatubbee signed the Treaty of the Choctaw Trading House on 24 October 1816 , and the Treaty Ground on 18 October 1820 to cede land .
#Text=The US failed to prevent settlers from continuing to encroach on Choctaw territory .
#Text=Journey to Washington

#Text=In 1824 , Pushmataha , Mushulatubee , and Apuckshunubbee , the three chiefs of the Choctaw regional divisions , became concerned about the encroaching settlement of European Americans and the unwillingness of local authorities to respect Indian land titles .

#Text=They still hoped to offset the government 's push for removal west of the Mississippi River and resolved to take their case to the Federal government in Washington , D.C. Pushmataha led the delegation ; they sought either expulsion of white settlers from deeded lands in Arkansas , or compensation in land and cash for such lands . [ 1 ]

#Text=The group also consisted of Talking Warrior , Red Fort , Nittahkachee , Col. Robert Cole and David Folsom , both ( mixed-race ) Choctaw ; Captain Daniel McCurtain ; and Major John Pitchlynn , the U.S. Interpreter . [ 2 ]

#Text=They planned to travel the Natchez Trace to Nashville , then to Lexington , Kentucky ; onward to Maysville , Kentucky ; across the Ohio River ( called the Spaylaywitheepi by the Shawnee ) northward to Chillicothe , Ohio ( former principal town of the Shawnee ) ; then finally east over the " National Highway " to Washington City . [ 2 ]
#Text=While in Washington , the chief also met with the Marquis de Lafayette , who was visiting Washington , D.C. for the last time .
#Text=He hailed him as a fellow aged warrior who , though foreign , rose to high renown in the American cause .
#Text=You are one of our fathers that fought in the War with Gen. George Washington .
#Text=We take you here by the hand as a friend and a father .
#Text=We have always walked in the white paths of peace ; and in those paths we have traveled to visit you .
#Text=We offer you pure hands , which have never been stained with the blood of Americans .
#Text=-- We live in the south , where the sun shines hot upon us .

#Text=We have been neighbors to the French , neighbors to the Spaniards , and neighbors to the English : but now our only neighbors are the Americans , in the midst of whom we live as friends and brothers .
#Text=— Mushulatubba , The Essex Register , 2 December 1824 . [ 3 ]
#Text=Candidate for U.S. Congress
#Text=In 1830 Mushulatubbee announced his candidacy for office in Mississippi in the Port Gibson Correspondent , as reported by the Christian Mirror and N.H. Observer ( 15 July 1830 ) . [ 4 ]
#Text=To the voters of Mississippi .
#Text=Fellow Citizens : -I have fought for you , I have been by your own act , made a citizen of your state ;
#Text=... According to your laws I am an American citizen , ... I have always battled on the side of this republic ...
#Text=I have been told by my white brethren , that the pen of history is impartial , and that in after years , our forlorn kindred will have justice and ' mercy too ' .
#Text=— Mushulatubba , Christian Mirror and N.H. Observer , July 1830 . [ 4 ]
#Text=The US government forced the Choctaw to remove to Indian Territory west of the Mississippi River .
#Text=Mushulatubbee was the chief of his division during the removal and for a time after their resettlement in what became Oklahoma .
#Text=The government had encouraged the Choctaw to resettle in their former clan divisions .
#Text=Relocation soon led to changes in the society in which those clan divisions became less important .
#Text=In 1838 Mushulatubbee died of smallpox in present-day Arkansas and was buried near Cameron , Oklahoma in Le Flore County , Oklahoma .
